heading: enhanced mris zero in on cancer
subheading: inert gases are being used to produce clearer mris that could enable doctors to use safer surgical procedures. by heidi kriz.
author: lindsey arent
text: it used to be that when doctors squinted at an x-ray image of diseased lungs, all they could make out was what looked like big blobs of wet cotton. now with a new technique that mixes hyperpolarized gases with magnetic resonance imaging, doctors can see images down to the millimeter, enabling them to perform more precise procedures.read ongoing med-tech coverage - - - - - -"now, we can prolong the lives of people with extensive lung disease, who we would probably otherwise have had to sit back and watch die," said dr. thomas daniel of the university of virginia health sciences center.daniel, a thoracic surgeon, has used the special mris to identify diseased parts of the lungs that should be removed. he uses a very delicate and tricky procedure called a "lung-shaving operation.""the dangerous aspect is knowing what to take out," daniel said. "now we can tell."patients gulp a lung full of one of two noble gases -- helium or xenon -- that have been hyperpolarized with lasers. they then hold their breath for several seconds during an mri scan using a specially outfitted machine. noble gases, also called inert gases, are named so because they generally don't react chemically with other elements.when gases are hyperpolarized, it means a large quantity of the atomic nuclei's "spin" -- a magnetic property of quantum particles -- point in the same direction. the hyperpolarized gases provide an mri signal that is about 100,000 times stronger than the signal produced by water, the substance that is normally visualized by mri scans.consequently, the much more precise images aid doctors in removing affected areas of the lung.previously most of the research into leveraging gases with mris has been done using helium, which emits a stronger signal than xenon. but one of the few sources for the specific isotope of helium needed -- helium 3 -– is extremely rare, coming from old hydrogen bombs. helium 3 is also pricey -- it costs several hundred dollars per liter, which is the amount required for one mri session.
